chapter.title: Module 3 Learning Objectives
chapter.content:
Module 3 Learning Objectives

This module addresses the second stage of backward design – assessment. This includes one dimension of differentiating instructional techniques – by product, or the demonstration of learning that is to be assessed. Here are the learning objectives for this module.

 By the end of this lesson, participants will be able to:

  1. name at least three reasons for differentiating by product
  2. describe at least two differences between formative and summative assessment
  3. name four types of assessments
  4. produce at least one differentiated, summative assessment for the learning objective from the prior module
  5. write a reflection on  how designing assessments before planning activities affects the choice of learning activities

chapter.title: Changing the Thinking About Assessment
chapter.content:
Changing the Thinking About Assessment

Often when thinking about assessment, the first thing that comes to mind are the kind of final, high-stakes tests that both teachers and students dread. In the differentiated classroom, however, there are many more types of, and times for, assessment than you may be familiar with. These need not all be time-consuming, formal events. Pre-assessments can be done as casually as a class discussion, as formally as an essay, or as simply as reviewing previous work. Assessment during lessons might be through observation, interim products, or quick surveys. Final assessments can, of course, be quizzes or tests, but they can also be culminating activities like posters, skits, or presentations.

chapter.title: Why Differentiate By Product?
chapter.content:
Why Differentiate By Product?

Assessment can be a vexing problem in a differentiated classroom. If students are not all doing the same thing, how can we assess their work? One way to begin sorting things out is to make a distinction between two types of assessment: formative and summative. Formative assessment is an ongoing process during lessons, which is essential for differentiation because it demonstrates learning progress and indicates where instructional adjustments may be needed. It is a feedback loop which teachers use “both to provide feedback to students about their progress and to guide decisions about next steps in the learning process” (TEAL, 2010, p. 1). This kind of assessment is usually informal, using such measures as entry/exit cards, surveys, reflection journals, and quick writes. Differentiation may be used here, but is not always necessary; in fact, this type of assessment is used to inform differentiation.

Summative assessment, on the other hand, assesses the learning that has occurred by the end of the lesson, or the sum of learning achieved. It is the final product or demonstration of learning that shows whether and to what extent students have met learning objectives. And it is in this final product, in summative assessment, that differentiation can be useful. According to one expert, “Differentiated assessment is varying the assessment product or method to make the assessment as fair as possible for all students. Keep in mind that fair and equal are not synonyms” (Harriman, 2013). Echoing the language of UDL, Tomlinson and Sousa state that effective summative assessments “make room for student variance by providing multiple means of representation, multiple means of expression, and multiple means of engagement.” They continue:  “Although the criteria for success on the assessment will generally stay the same for all students … the formats, directions, and working conditions can vary as needed to ensure that a full range of students has ample opportunity to express critical knowledge, understanding, and skills” (2011, p. 76).

We have seen that students begin at different levels and that they absorb and retain new skills and information at different rates and in different ways. Although they may be in the same class, we can’t expect a student struggling with basic mathematical operations to perform well on algebra tasks. Both experience and the principles of UDL show that students demonstrate their strengths in different ways. Why, then, would we expect a single assessment or product to bring out the best in all of them? We cannot. Students need multiple means to demonstrate what they have learned. The actual products may be differentiated; some alternatives to standard methods of assessment have already been mentioned, and more will be examined in greater detail shortly. Or, in the case of group efforts, students may fill different roles according to their individual strengths. In addition, the stress of the type of testing often used as the final assessment can actually suppress the recall of information needed to answer the questions (Tomlinson & Sousa, 2011, p. 71). Allowing students to demonstrate their knowledge in other ways can reduce or remove stress, allowing for greater access to the knowledge students actually possess. As will be seen, these alternative assessments can also be designed to deepen and extend learning, or to provide a means for students to transfer what they have learned to real-life situations.

chapter.title: Backward Design, Stage 2: Assessment
chapter.content:
Backward Design, Stage 2: Assessment

It is designing this summative assessment that forms stage 2 of the backward design process. This stage is where backward design departs in a substantial way from standard lesson planning because the assessment is designed BEFORE planning the lesson’s learning activities. Logically, it makes sense, though: only if we know what evidence will be adequate to demonstrate achievement of our learning objectives can we plan activities that will help students get to that point. Matching the assessment to specific instructional goals gives a clear focus for the learning activities planned in stage 3.

As covered earlier in this course, assessments need not be limited to common paper-and-pencil measures. They must, however, demonstrate direct evidence of student proficiency in the areas specified in the learning objectives. They must also provide a means of identifying different levels of student performance, whether by simple scoring, as with tests, or through rubrics or other means that identify performance levels such as beginning, competent, or advanced. Assessments may be assigned by a teacher, or chosen by students from among a variety of options. Allowing student choice not only provides differentiation, but also can improve motivation and empowerment. However, assigned assessments may be necessary to meet specific instructional goals. As with learning objectives, the design of an assessment is dependent on teacher intent. The point is what teachers and students learn from these assessments, not how they are done.

chapter.title: Types of Assessment
chapter.content:
Types of Assessment

In general, four types of assessment are most commonly used: selected response, constructed response, authentic, and project based. We will review each of these.

  • Selected response assessments include the familiar multiple-choice and true-false tests: students select an answer from among those provided. The questions on these instruments have one right answer. They can be effective as either formative or summative assessments, especially for determining students’ memory for facts or for testing simple applications. They are easy to use and score, and they can be used as practice for the high-stakes tests many students must take.

  • In constructed response assessments, students construct their own answers in response to a question or problem. Such assessments can include essays, explanations, fill-in-the-blanks, and problem solving. Again, they may be formative or summative; they can determine what students can produce from their own knowledge or memory, or how much understanding students have of a given topic or skill. They may be differentiated, for example: by length (an essay compared to a paragraph); by the level of complexity required in the answers (restatement compared to inference); or by the level of scaffolding provided (with or without a list of vocabulary words or math formulas). High quality assessment of this sort that requires students to justify their answers can actually improve student learning: “There is substantial evidence that learning is facilitated by constructing explanations and arguments” (National Research Council 2012, p. 116).

  • Authentic assessments are based on real-world activities and needs. Low-level literacy students may be just learning to write their names and addresses; in that case, an authentic assessment might be filling out a school registration form or library card application. For higher-level students reading about current events or neighborhood issues, an assessment could be writing a letter to the editor, drafting a petition, or computing the cost of changes in a school or municipal program.

  • Project based assessments tend to be long-term, multi-stage activities or inquiries, involving many skills. Science students, for example, might examine how various environmental issues are represented in their own community. Assessment could then be through the preparation of reports, presentations or brochures for various audiences, making proposals for community action, or taking action themselves. While there may and should be formative assessment in the course of these activities, such complex assessments are summative by nature. How to measure student performance on such projects will be discussed shortly.

Assessment may be thought of in three ways: assessment of, for, and as learning. Assessment of learning is summative. Assessment for learning is formative, helping teachers determine whether instruction must be adapted for optimal student learning. Summative assessment, so often seen as merely measurement, can also be designed as learning, “deliberately designed to teach and improve, not just measure” (Wiggins 1998, p. 21). Well-designed authentic or project-based assessments can certainly function in this way. So can a complex related form called performance assessment. In this type of assessment, students work through a variety of steps or strategies that require using and applying learned skills in meaningful settings. The environmental study mentioned above is one example of performance assessment. Here is another related to students learning health-related concepts and vocabulary:  Can they go through the steps of making a real or mock appointment at a clinic and explaining the symptoms of their illness to a health care worker?

chapter.title: Differentiation By Product
chapter.content:
Differentiation By Product

One example of a differentiated product is contained in this lesson plan. English language learners (ELLs) who are employees in a grocery store kitchen are working on the correct use of comparative and superlative adjectives. Their assessment will be writing and performing mock customer/employee conversations. Much of the lesson will be the same for all students:  review of adjective forms, discussion of situations in which these conversations might take place, written practice of adjective forms. Eventually, however, students will split into pairs to write and perform their conversations. These are heterogeneous pairs assigned by the teacher, so there is a higher-level and lower-level student in each one. Here is where the products will diverge. Each pair chooses a different section of the grocery store where their conversation will take place (dairy, produce, frozen food, etc.). Each pair produces and performs its own conversation to meet certain explicit requirements stated by the teacher. The activity within each pair is differentiated by readiness:  the lower-level student takes on the easier more formulaic role of customer, while the higher-level student has the more open-ended employee role. Each conversation will be different; therefore, the products of this lesson are differentiated. Now the teacher has to decide how student performance will be evaluated on these differentiated products.

chapter.title: Measurement
chapter.content:
Measurement

And so we come to the question of measurement. Of course it can be the kind of simple, standard scoring for the familiar worksheets, tests and quizzes. That will not do, though, for the complex and differentiated assessments described earlier. For these, a rubric can be a most useful tool. Rubrics are detailed scoring charts that contain information about the skills to be assessed and the expected levels of performance. They contain three components:

  • criteria (what is to be learned, matching learning objectives)

  • quality indicators (different levels of achievement for each criterion)

  • numerical scores for each criterion and indicator

For example, consider the rubric below for the grocery store workplace lesson plan discussed above. With this rubric, each student could be scored on each criterion and receive a final score indicating overall performance. Note that this rubric shows both the teacher and students what is expected for an effective presentation. A student who scores 4 or less out of a possible 12 points knows what she needs to do to improve her performance. In this way, the rubric itself becomes a teaching tool: “Rubrics can improve student performance, as well as monitor it, by making teachers’ expectations clear and by showing students how to meet these expectations” (Andrade, n.d.).

chapter.title: Rubric Examples and Aids
chapter.content:
Rubric Examples and Aids

There is no denying that preparing effective rubrics can be time-consuming. They do, however, provide the benefit of looking closely at what constitutes effective performance. Sharing rubrics with students from the start also allows them to know exactly what they are aiming for. Fortunately, there are many good examples of rubrics and aids for making them. chapter.title: Review, Tasks and Resources
chapter.content:
Review, Tasks and Resources

Review

In this module we have discussed:

  • differentiating by product due to differences in student readiness in a given area, to differing rates and methods of assimilating and retaining new information and skills, and to the need for providing multiple means of demonstrating knowledge

  • formative assessment as undifferentiated, conducted during a lesson or unit, used to inform differentiation and instruction

  • summative demonstration of learning conducted at end of lesson or unit, differentiated when appropriate

  • assessments as selected response, constructed response, authentic, project based, or performance

Tasks

  1. Module 3 Quiz: Take this short quiz to test your learning. A passing grade is 80%; you may take it as many times as you wish and refer back to the module whenever necessary.

  2. Module 3 Exercise: Download and complete this exercise, which includes writing your own differentiated summative assessment for the learning objective from the prior module.

  3. Write a reflection: Consider a lesson you currently teach. Did you design the assessment before planning activities? If so, how did it help determine the activities to be used? If not, how might developing the assessment before planning activities have changed your choices? Post it in the COP: https://community.lincs.ed.gov/discussion/online-course-differentiated-instruction-and-lesson-planning-assessment
